channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: OPEC Members and Russia Set to Meet as Europe Faces Energy Crisis
item.description: Saudi Arabia appears determined to raise prices and continue coordinating with Russia during the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A municipal worker removing the remnants of a missile, which hit overnight, from the garden of a home in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukraine Expels Some Russian Troops in South
item.description: Moscow’s retreat has pulled back the curtain on a panorama of ruined towns and empty villages left in its wake.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops moving through the recently recaptured village of Yatskivka on Tuesday. Ukraine has recaptured cities in the northeast, the east and now the south.

item.title: Russians Fleeing the Draft Find an Unlikely Haven in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: Tens of thousands of men have ended up in places like Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet territory, that normally see few refugees but are willing to take them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri, a 36-year-old artist from Siberia, took three days to get by bus and train to Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, where he now lives in a 20-bed hostel room.

item.title: Tear Gas, a Stampede, and an Indonesian Family Shattered
item.description: Muhammad Yulianto and Devi Ratna Sari took their young son to his first soccer match. The young couple were among the 125 who died in the tragedy at the Indonesian stadium.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images
item.media:description: Muhammad Alfiansyah, 11, with photographs of his parents, in Malang on Tuesday.

item.title: 4 Women Will Staff U.K. Base in Antarctica
item.description: They emerged from an applicant pool of thousands to run the world’s most southerly post office, monitor penguins and manage the wild landscape on Goudier Island.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.media:credit: Dietmar Denger/Laif, via Redux
item.media:description: Port Lockroy base on Goudier Island is managed by the U.K. Antarctic Heritage Trust. Assignment there is not for the faint hearted.

item.title: North Korea Fires Ballistic Missile Over Japan in Major Escalation
item.description: The last time Pyongyang launched a weapon over Japan was in 2017, when Donald J. Trump was president and Kim Jong-un seemed intent on escalating conflict with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A screen showing images of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, during a news update in Tokyo on Tuesday. North Korea’s missile launch prompted an alert in Japan that morning.

item.title: Scouting for Firewood, or for Russia? On the Front Line in Ukraine.
item.description: Outside the city of Lyman, Ukrainian troops ran across a 69-year-old Soviet veteran. He was placed in an improvised blindfold. All were enveloped in the fog of war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers escorting a 69-year-old man named Aleksandr, whom they suspected of spying for the Russians, near the city of Lyman in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Protecting the Peatlands of Ireland as Fuel Costs Skyrocket
item.description: One in seven Irish households still burn peat for heat. New rules are aimed at discouraging a practice that many consider part of the culture.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seamus Caulfield, a retired archaeology professor, cutting peat using a traditional angled spade called a sleán, on his family’s land in Belderrig, Ireland.

item.title: Iran Attacks Kurdish Positions Across the Border in Iraq
item.description: Tehran has blamed Kurdish groups for fomenting some of the protests that have convulsed Iran for almost three weeks.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Damage from an Iranian attack near the city of Suleimaniyah, Iraq, last week.

item.title: Trial Opens for Bruce Lehrmann, Man Accused of Rape in Australia’s Parliament House
item.description: The trial of the Australian man accused of sexually assaulting Brittany Higgins will be viewed against the backdrop of the global #MeToo movement.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Brittany Higgins arriving at Supreme Court in Canberra, Australia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Journalist Percy Lapid Is Fatally Shot in the Philippines
item.description: The radio host Percival Mabasa was killed during an ambush, the police said. He had been a prominent critic of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and his predecessor, Rodrigo Duterte.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Family members grieving Percival Mabasa at their home in Manila on Tuesday.

item.title: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss Drops Plan to Cut Tax Rate on High Earners
item.description: The announcement was a major capitulation by Prime Minister Liz Truss’s government after the tax cuts it announced roiled financial markets and drew widespread criticism.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain, center, has been forced to change course during her Conservative Party’s showpiece annual conference in Birmingham, England.

item.title: François Legault Wins Re-election in Quebec
item.description: Voters in Quebec gave a second term to Premier François Legault, who has shifted the province from a once fervent-independence movement to a nationalism focused on French Québécois identity.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Christinne Muschi/Reuters
item.media:description: Quebec’s premier, François Legault, speaking in May at a political convention in Drummondville, Quebec. He overwhelmingly won re-election Monday, according to preliminary results.

item.title: Éric Dupond-Moretti, French Justice Minister, Faces Trial
item.description: Éric Dupond-Moretti opened investigations of judges he had clashed with as a lawyer, prompting accusations that he had abused his position to settle scores.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Ludovic Marin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Éric Dupond-Moretti, France’s justice minister, leaving a cabinet meeting last month in Paris.

item.title: E.U. Negotiators Strike Deal on Russian Oil Price Cap
item.description: The cap, championed by the United States, would deprive the Kremlin of tens of billions of dollars annually. Experts warn that implementation will be difficult.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Tatiana Meel/Reuters
item.media:description: A crude oil terminal near the port city of Nakhodka, Russia. With oil prices at a high, Russia is raking in billions of dollars in revenue, even as it sells smaller quantities.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry to Be Awarded Today
item.description: The third Nobel awarded this year, it is the week’s final science prize.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Angela Weiss

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine gains ground in south
item.description: Plus Elon Musk suggests buying Twitter at his original price and North Korea fires a missile over Japan
item.dc:creator: Jessica Cheung and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph taken during the government-arranged tour for journalists showing a destroyed bridge in Sviatohirsk on Monday.

item.title: After the Storm, the Mold: Warming Is Worsening Another Costly Disaster
item.description: Mold in homes is a costly crisis that often accompanies hurricanes and flooding, and climate change is amplifying the rain that feeds outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin and Emily Kask
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine’s Top Diplomat Tries to Counter Russia’s Narrative on Africa Tour
item.description: “I arrived here and I hear, ‘Russia and Ukraine are one people,’” Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, said in Senegal on the first stop of his 10-day trip across Africa.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Mady Camara
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, speaking at the United Nations Security Council in September.

item.title: Paid to Fight, Even in Ancient Greece
item.description: DNA from a 2,500-year-old battlefield in Sicily reveals that mercenary soldiers were common, if not the Homeric ideal.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:credit: Stefano Vassallo
item.media:description: A mass grave of troops from the second Battle of Himera in Sicily in 409 B.C. One-fourth of the combatants are thought to have been mercenaries, compared to two-thirds in the first Battle of Himera seven decades earlier.

item.title: Florida’s GOP Leaders Opposed Climate Aid. Now They’re Depending on It.
item.description: Senior Republican politicians in the state have opposed federal action against global warming, which is making storms like Hurricane Ian more destructive.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Damage to the Sanibel Causeway, the only road in or out of Sanibel Island, in southwest Florida on Sept. 29.

item.title: Rebekah Vardy Ordered to Pay Legal Fees in ‘Wagatha Christie’ Case
item.description: Ms. Vardy will pay 90 percent of Coleen Rooney’s legal costs, an estimated $1.7 million, after losing a libel case that proved irresistible to the British press.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Peter Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Rebekah Vardy in London in May, arriving for a hearing in the so-called Wagatha Christie libel case.

item.title: A Public Health Success Story
item.description: We revisit the subject of Covid and racial inequities.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Andi Rice/Bloomberg
item.media:description: A health care worker from Alabama Regional Medical Services administering a Covid vaccine in Birmingham, Ala., in 2021.

item.title: Russia’s War in Ukraine Sends Swedish Marines Into the Arms of NATO
item.description: Russia’s war in Ukraine has sent marines from famously neutral Sweden into the arms of NATO, where they have been working with American forces.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Kenny Holston
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American and Swedish marines participating in a military exercise near Berga Naval Base in Sweden.

item.title: What Video Footage Reveals About the Protests in Iran
item.description: The New York Times analyzed dozens of videos circulating online for insights about what is propelling the demonstrations, and how women are leading the movement.
item.dc:creator: Nilo Tabrizy and Haley Willis

item.title: Climate Change for Preschoolers: ‘Octonauts’ Explores Unmapped Ground
item.description: There are few books, shows or other tools to help parents and teachers talk to preschoolers about global warming. “Octonauts: Above and Beyond” is one of the first to try.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

item.title: Nobel Prize in Physics Is Awarded to 3 Scientists for Work Exploring Quantum Weirdness
item.description: Alain Aspect, John F. Clauser and Anton Zeilinger were recognized for their experiments in an area that has broad implications for secure information transfer and quantum computing.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai, Cora Engelbrecht and Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Jonas Ekstromer/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Awarding the prize on Tuesday, the committee said that the scientists’ work had “opened doors to another world.”

item.title: Can New Vaccines Finally Eradicate Malaria?
item.description: Two new vaccines may finally turn back an ancient plague. But in unexpected ways, their arrival also complicates the path to ending the disease.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Kang-Chun Cheng
item.media:credit: Kang-Chun Cheng for The New York Times

item.title: South Korean Internet Giant Buys Poshmark in $1.2 Billion Deal
item.description: With its new acquisition — the company’s largest to date — Naver has gained a sizable foothold in North America’s secondhand retail market.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Heo Ran/Reuters
item.media:description: Sometimes referred to as “the Google of South Korea,” Naver has looked beyond Asia for its latest acquisitions.

item.title: Zelensky promises a ‘clear and fair’ approach in reclaimed territory.
item.dc:creator: Juston Jones
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers driving near the village of Oskil in eastern Ukraine, during a media tour arranged by the Zelensky government on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine’s advances against Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers are seen in a military vehicle amidst destroyed houses in Oskil, Ukraine, on Monday, October 3, 2022.

item.title: CDC Ends Country-by-Country Covid Travel Advisories
item.description: The agency said it would no longer maintain a list of coronavirus travel warnings because “fewer countries are testing or reporting Covid-19 cases,” limiting its ability to assess travel risks.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing in Johannesburg. The announcement came as data reporting about the pandemic has been scaled back around the world.

item.title: Blinken Meets With Gustavo Petro of Colombia Amid Differences
item.description: The Biden administration disagrees with President Gustavo Petro’s views on the drug war, Venezuela and Cuba, but hopes to retain the historically strong ties the United States has with Bogotá.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Guillermo Legaria/Getty Images
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, right, and Colombia’s president, Gustavo Petro, speaking at a joint news conference on Monday in Bogotá.

item.title: Art Withers in a Country Where Anything Can Be Deemed a Threat
item.description: In Bangladesh, a crackdown on free speech has left filmmakers in a Kafkaesque bind as their movies are blocked for vague reasons.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Sazzad Hossain/SOPA Images/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Film directors and other artists behind a barbed wire wall they erected as a symbol of the censorship they are facing in Bangladesh.

item.title: Russia’s Small Nuclear Arms Are a Risk For Putin and Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has 2,000 small nuclear weapons, but their utility on the battlefield may not be worth the longer-term costs.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.media:credit: Alexander Nemenov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The atomic threats of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may come as a shock to Americans who have barely thought about nuclear arms in recent decades.

item.title: In Retreat on Ukrainian Fronts, Russia Shows Signs of Disarray
item.description: Confusion and recriminations marked the Russian efforts to call up draftees and claim sovereignty over Ukrainian territory, as well as the Russian response to battlefield setbacks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Carlotta Gall and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph taken during a Ukraine government-arranged tour for journalists showing Ukrainian soldiers in the town of Oskil, in eastern Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Tweets on Ending the War in Ukraine Draw Backlash
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky swiftly dismissed the entrepreneur’s suggestion on Twitter, and the Kremlin’s spokesman called it a “very positive” development with caveats.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Jim Watson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Election Deniers in U.S. Push Idea of Voting Fraud in Brazil
item.description: Some prominent election denialists in the United States are using Brazil to try to whip up concern about the approaching midterms.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Berzon and Ken Bensinger
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Electoral observers checked the integrity of electronic ballots in Brasília on Sunday.

item.title: Small Leak Is Still Visible From Nord Stream 2 pipeline, Swedish Officials Say
item.description: Damage to the gas line was discovered last week under the Baltic Sea.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Danish Defense, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by the Danish military last week showing gas bubbles from the Nord Stream 2 leak in the Baltic Sea.

item.title: Three Ways to Build Back Smarter After Hurricane Ian
item.description: Big storms are becoming more common. That makes it crucial to take climate change into account when rebuilding.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction from Hurricane Ian in Fort Myers Beach, Fla.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Indonesia Investigates Its Soccer Tragedy
item.description: Plus Brazil’s elections move to a runoff and Ukraine surges forward in the Donbas.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Cheung and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Mast Irham/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: People pay condolences to the victims of the soccer match riot and stampede outside Kanjuruhan Stadium in Malang, East Java, Indonesia, on Monday.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Appeal Hearing Set for Oct. 25, Russian Court Says
item.description: The United States has sought the release of the W.N.B.A. star, who pleaded guilty to drug possession and was sentenced to nine years.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, at a court hearing outside of Moscow in August.

item.title: Brazil Braces for ‘White-Knuckle Race’ Between Bolsonaro and Lula
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro had once looked doomed in the country’s high-stakes election. But now, in a runoff, the right-wing incumbent has a path to re-election.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters gathering in front of President Jair Bolsonaro’s residence in Rio de Janeiro as votes were counted on Sunday.

item.title: Victoria and Albert Museum Reverses Course and Removes Sackler Name
item.description: The museum’s director had previously said he was not going to erase the name of the Sackler family, which founded Purdue Pharma, the creator of an addictive opioid painkiller.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Carl Court/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Victoria and Albert Museum in London is removing the name of its Sackler Courtyard.

item.title: Deadly Soccer Clash in Indonesia Puts Police Tactics in Spotlight
item.description: Experts say officers are almost never held accountable for their actions. And in a huge police budget, millions are spent on tear gas, batons and other devices deployed during protests.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images
item.media:description: Indonesian riot police clashed with protesters in Jakarta after official election results were announced in May 2019.

item.title: U.S. Said to Plan New Limits on China’s A.I. and Supercomputing Firms
item.description: The new rules could be the most sweeping action taken yet by the Biden administration to thwart China’s access to American technology that powers data centers and supercomputers.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Ana Swanson and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Long Wei/Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A data center in Hangzhou, China. If enacted, new rules would be the strongest push to date by the United States to hit at China’s flourishing supercomputer and data center market.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Condemns Protests Gripping Country
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, speaking for the first time about the uprising, accused the U.S. and Israel of fomenting unrest and voiced support for the crackdown on protesters.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Wana News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, reviewing the country’s armed forces at a graduation ceremony in Tehran on Monday.

item.title: Head of Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Released From Detention
item.description: The detention by Russia of Ihor Murashov had stoked concerns about the security of Europe’s largest nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in August.

item.title: Maggie Haberman Talks About Reporting on Donald Trump
item.description: He often utters falsehoods, but his speaking style is more strategic than it sometimes seems. Listen for the first time to audio clips from interviews with Maggie Haberman.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump in Warren, Mich., this weekend.

item.title: Ukraine’s First Lady Tells ‘60 Minutes’ of the War’s Impact
item.description: Olena Zelenska told CBS News that Russian attacks on schools, hospitals and residential areas have been a form of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Juston Jones
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olena Zelenska, the Ukrainian first lady, at a session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York last month.

item.title: Unearthing Everyday Life at an Ancient Site in Greece
item.description: Excavations in the Peloponnesian village of Iklaina are yielding rich insights into the lives of the Mycenaean civilization’s general population.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stirn
item.media:credit: Matt Stirn
item.media:description: An archaeologist carefully unearths a pottery fragment.

item.title: Nobel Prize Awarded to Scientist Who Sequenced Neanderthal Genome
item.description: Svante Pääbo, a Swedish geneticist, was honored for work that created a new field of ancient DNA studies and identified populations at higher risk of disease.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller

item.title: Indonesian human rights official says tear gas likely played a key role in the disaster.
item.description: An initial examination shows that police also used violent force against fans. Without gas, the tragedy might have been avoided, the organization said.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Mast Irham/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Police inside the Kanjuruhan Stadium on Monday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Nord Stream leakages stop.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Danish Defence Command, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images

item.title: The investigation will take two weeks, an official says.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: H Prabowo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Police officers trying to stop fans from entering the field during a clash between fans at Kanjuruhan Stadium in Malang, Indonesia, on Sunday.

item.title: Bolsonaro Outperforms Polls and Forces Runoff Against Lula in Brazil’s Election
item.description: The two political titans will face off again later this month in a race widely seen as a major test for one of the world’s largest democracies.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

item.title: Russia’s Annexation Claim Is News to Residents of Lyman, Ukraine
item.description: Without access to electricity, radios or the internet, residents of Lyman said they were unaware of President Vladimir V. Putin’s grandiose celebration of an illegal land grab.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A badly damaged building in Lyman, a strategic rail hub.

item.title: Nord Stream Pipelines Have Stopped Leaking After Earlier Damage
item.description: Both European and Russian leaders have said that ruptures discovered undersea were an act of sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Danish Defense Command, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gas leaks were discovered on Nord Stream pipelines in the Baltic Sea last week.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops Hunt Demoralized Russian Stragglers in Lyman
item.description: A major Russian newspaper said the Russian troops, facing defeat in Lyman, had fled with “empty eyes” after barely escaping with their lives.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank near a recaptured area north of Lyman in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: On Russian TV, the Kremlin emphasizes a fight against all of the West, not just Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
